Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as a0969c70c0e5a38c0e65f558e254f1af062b33b4
Need more details here.  Where does the redfish schemas declare that the subscription should be deleted after the retries terminate?

I added the link and short description in the commit message.

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0268_2024.3.html

```
DeliveryRetryPolicy:
 - `TerminateAfterRetries`:
  This value shall indicate the subscription is terminated after the
  maximum number of retries is reached, specified by the
  DeliveryRetryAttempts property in the event service.
```
That says "the subscription is terminated" not "the subscription is deleted".  Any idea why the discrepancy?

I also think they seem ambiguous between "deleted” or terminated".

Perhaps wouldn’t they be indicating the differences what it caused – either by request, or by a result of certain conditions (like retry failures)?

I think if the result of termination may be different from deletion, I would expect that some kind of the indication that tells about the terminated subscription, but there seems no such state field of the subscription.



I found a few references related to the subscription.

1) DMTF redfish spec - 
https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.21.0.html

> Section 12.1.2:
| Terminate a subscription if the number of delivery errors exceeds pre-configured thresholds.
…
| Subsequent requests to subscription resources that have been terminated respond with the HTTP 404 Not Found status code.

2)  The openbmc event service doc - https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/377ed14df4913010752ee2faff994a50e12a6316/designs/redfish-eventservice.md?plain=1#L860-L862

It also says

> ### Push style events (HTTP/HTTPS):

>... If establishing connection fails, it retries for configured
retry attempts (DeliveryRetryAttempts) and delete the subscription if it reaches
threshold limit.

Wouldn't this be implying that the subscription termination will result in the deletion of it?

I think this one is the key:
``` 
If establishing connection fails, it retries for configured
retry attempts (DeliveryRetryAttempts) and delete the subscription if it reaches
threshold limit.```


Maybe that's what Appu intended to happen, but that's never been the behavior so far as I'm aware, and we shouldn't be quoting OpenBMC docs in regards to Redfish.  We should be quoting DMTF.

If that's not clear, we should work with DMTF to get the wording put somewhere on what the correct behavior is here.

Thanks for suggestion.
I've submitted an issue (question) to DMTF/Redfish - https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/issues/6221

I got a response from DMTF.

---
https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/issues/6221#issuecomment-2386208525

>Does this subscription termination also mean that the subscription will need to be deleted?

Termination has meant we delete the subscription. This is the reason we added the `DeliveryRetryPolicy` property to allow for the subscription to continue to exist in the service, but in a disabled state.

I can see how this semantic isn't clear. The closest text I can find is in the Redfish Spec:

>To terminate the event stream at any time, either the client or the service can delete the subscription.

---
ACK.  Good enough for me.
In addition, https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/pull/6230/ modifies the schema to clarify the behavior of subscription termination

This patch needed rebased, and had some lifetime issues as written.  I've rewritten some portions to set up shared_from_this so we get proper lifetimes for subscriptions on delete that might not have all their connections closed.

I haven't tested it, so PTAL and see if it passes your tests.

I found out there is a bug in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/65720 and I submitted a fix https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75296.

I'll rebase it when ready

With this, I'm seeing the bad_weak_ptr like
```
Oct 15 22:48:40 p10bmc bmcwebd[6227]: terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_weak_ptr'
Oct 15 22:48:40 p10bmc bmcwebd[6227]:   what():  bad_weak_ptr
Oct 15 22:48:41 p10bmc systemd[1]: bmcweb.service: Main process exited, code=dumped, status=6/ABRT
Oct 15 22:48:41 p10bmc systemd[1]: bmcweb.service: Failed with result 'core-dump'.
Oct 15 23:03:04 p10bmc systemd[1]: Started Start bmcwebd server.
```

I think this seems related to the class `Subscription` and there seems a mismatch when it is shared.

I'll keep looking at it.

```
class Subscription : std::enable_shared_from_this<Subscription>

...

            client->sendDataWithCallback(
....
                std::bind_front(&Subscription::resHandler, this,
                                shared_from_this()));
                                
                                
```
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75296 merged. So I think we are good here?

Even after rebase, this still does not work.

1. When using `shared_from_this()` (e.g. patchset 11), it caused `bad_weak_ptr` exception like
```
Oct 15 22:48:40 p10bmc bmcwebd[6227]: terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_weak_ptr'
Oct 15 22:48:40 p10bmc bmcwebd[6227]:   what():  bad_weak_ptr
```

I think in the process of this code path, Subscription shared_ptr may have been released.

2. Even with the change as the current patchset 14, it still fails to cause SEQV like
```
Oct 18 17:01:08 p10bmc systemd[1]: bmcweb.service: Main process exited, code=dumped, status=11/SEGV
Oct 18 17:01:08 p10bmc systemd[1]: bmcweb.service: Failed with result 'core-dump'.
```

----
I'll keep looking
where does that exception get thrown from?

With patcheset 12 (and with rebase on top of the current master) , the exception comes from `shared_from_this()` here.

```
            client->sendDataWithCallback(
....
                std::bind_front(&Subscription::resHandler, this,
                                shared_from_this()));
```
To prove it, add the line like

```
@@ -318,6 +318,9 @@ class Subscription : std::enable_shared_from_this<Subscription>

         if (client)
         {
+            BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR("Before shared_from_this");
+            auto self = shared_from_this();
+            BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR("After shared_from_this");
             client->sendDataWithCallback(
                 std::move(msg), userSub.destinationUrl,
                 static_cast<ensuressl::VerifyCertificate>(
```

Then, an exception throw is observed here when a new event is occurred.

```
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [DEBUG http_connection.hpp:302] Setting completion handler
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [DEBUG http_response.hpp:258] 0x2688b90 setting completion handler
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [DEBUG routing.hpp:653] Matched rule '/redfish/v1/EventService/Actions/EventService.SubmitTestEvent/' POST / 32
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [DEBUG dbus_privileges.hpp:50] userName = root userRole = priv-admin
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [DEBUG query.hpp:123] setup redfish route
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: [ERROR event_service_manager.hpp:321] Before shared_from_this
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]: terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_weak_ptr'
Oct 18 19:17:02 p10bmc bmcwebd[286]:   what():  bad_weak_ptr
```

It turns out the cause is due to Subscription with `private` enable_shared_from_this inheritance.  (Some more reference is https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39937112/stdenable-shared-from-this-public-vs-private).

The fix is to do like
```
class Subscription : std::enable_shared_from_this<Subscription>
-->
class Subscription : public std::enable_shared_from_this<Subscription>
```

Now it works.

I'd like to do more testing as I observed some missed deletion of subscription after TerminateAfterRetries
```

There was a missing `deleter` setup at Subscription PATCH (for push style).
It should now be fixed and working.
I meant - POST (subscription creation)
Done
Looks good, just one nit on using an existing utility function.
nit: Should this be using getSubscriptionId()?

Previously, there was a different/separate variable `subId` (which was called getSubscriptionId()) from this `id`. It turns out it was an error and thus `subId` was removed.

In addition, getSubscriptionId() and setSubscriptionId() are used once - which seem overly done.
So, I'd rather remove those functions but use `userSub.id` directly (in a separate commit).
For the reference, I submitted https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75459 to remove getSubscriptionId() and setSubscriptionId()
Acknowledged
